Título: A Life of Picasso III: The Triumphant Years
sinopsis: The third, penultimate installment in Richardson’s biography spans a dauntingly complicated time in Picasso’s life and in European history.
A former child warrior gives literary voice to the violence and killings he both witnessed and perpetrated during the Sierra Leone civil war.
A scholar finds that religion meant power for Greek women.
Ellison was seemingly cursed by his failure to follow up “Invisible Man.”
Actual “Peanuts” cartoons movingly illustrate this portrait of the strip’s creator, presented here as a profoundly lonely and unhappy man.
A memoir about waiting tables at the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant Per Se.
A civilian teacher at the Military Academy offers a significant perspective on a crucial social and political force: honor.
Of the many biographies of Henry Morton Stanley, Jeal’s, which profits from his access to an immense new trove of material, is the most complete and readable.
With nuance and complexity, Lilla examines how we managed to separate, in a fashion, church and state.
Tomalin presents Hardy as a fascinating case study in mid-Victorian literary sociology.
The story of the man immortalized in “Out of Africa.”
Sharp criticism meets playful, absorbing biography in this study of Stein and Toklas.
An extraordinary look at the gulag’s impact on desperate individuals and families struggling to survive.
Individual testimony and broader events are skillfully interwoven.
The life of this novel’s heroine — a first lady who comes to realize, at the height of the Iraq war, that she has compromised her youthful ideals — is conspicuously modeled on that of Laura Bush.
The psychiatrist-narrator of this brainy, whimsical first novel believes that his beautiful, much-younger Argentine wife has been replaced by an exact double.
Mackey’s fictive world is an insular one of musicians composing, playing and talking jazz in the private language of their art.
This bravura first novel, set against a corruptly compelling Las Vegas landscape, revolves around the disappearance of a surly 12-year-old boy.
Ma’s novel, an important political statement, looks at China through the life of a dissident paralyzed at Tiananmen Square.
For Adrian — who is both a pediatrician and a divinity student — illness and a heightened spiritual state are closely related conditions.
A rookie paramedic in New York City is overwhelmed by the horrors of his job in this arresting, confrontational novel, informed by Burke’s five years of experience on city ambulances.

The caring, thoughtful hero of Earley’s engrossing first novel, “Jim the Boy,” is now 17 and confronting not only the eternal turmoil of love, but also venality and the frightening calls of duty and war.
In the opening story of Le’s first collection, a blocked writer succumbs to the easy temptations of “ethnic lit.”
Surfing offers this darkly exhilarating novel’s protagonist an escape from a drab Australian town.

Miles’s fine first novel takes the form of a letter from a stranded traveler, his life a compilation of regrets, who uses the time to digress on an impressive array of cultural issues, large and small.
Coetzee follows the late career of one Señor C, who, like Coetzee himself, is a South African writer transplanted to Australia and the author of a novel titled “Waiting for the Barbarians.”
In the title story of this expertly turned collection, Henry James and Joseph Conrad embody Ozick’s polarity of art and ardor.
Grief is converted into art in this bleak, forthright collection, centered on the death of the poet’s son.
A 60-year-old cherry farmer and former English teacher — an inversion of the classic Harrison hero — sets out on a trip west after being dumped by his wife.
Wideman’s novel — raw and astringent, yet with a high literary polish — explores the life of the psychiatrist and revolutionary Frantz Fanon.
A New York thriller, played out against the nasty world of global capitalism.

Título: Fine Just the Way It Is
sinopsis: These rich, bleak stories offer an American West in which the natural elements are murderous and folks aren’t much better.
In Tinti’s first novel, set in mid-19th-century New England, a con man teaches an orphan the art of the lie.

Título: Half of the World in Light
sinopsis: Herrera, known for portrayals of Chicano life, is unpredictable and wildly inventive.
In this enthralling novel, a boy goes underground with a defiant hippie indulging her maternal urge.
Revisiting the events of her novel “Gilead” from another perspective, Robinson has written an anguished pastoral, at once bitter and joyful.
Marcus Messner is a sophomore at a small, conservative Ohio college at the time of the Korean War. The novel he narrates, like Roth’s last two, is ruthlessly economical and relentlessly deathbound.
This novel’s despairing immigrant protagonist becomes intrigued with the real-life killing of a presumed anarchist in Chicago in 1908.
In his first story collection, Vann leads the reader to vital places while exorcizing demons born from the suicide of his father.
Barker’s new novel, about a group of British artists overtaken by World War I, concentrates more on the turmoil of love than on the trauma of war.
Chandler — and Bellow, too — peeps out from Price’s novel, in which an aspiring writer cum restaurant manager, mugged in the gentrifying Lower East Side of Manhattan, himself becomes a suspect.
Harvey is willing to take risks, and her reward is that richest, rarest thing, genuine poetry.

This powerful novel, centered on a half-Russian, half-Chechen, half-crazy fugitive in Germany, swims with operatives whose desperation to avert another 9/11 provokes a slow-­burning fire in every line.
Kunzru’s third novel is an extraordinary autumnal depiction of a failed ’60s radical.
James, a staunch formalist, is firmly situated in the sociable, plain-spoken tradition that runs from Auden through Larkin.
In this novel from the author of “Snow Falling on Cedars,” a schoolteacher nourishes a friendship with a privileged recluse.
Some of Wolff’s best work is concentrated here, revealing his gift for evoking the breadth of American experience.
A widowed Russian emigrant, fearfully navigating the strange city of London, learns that his home village is about to be inundated.

Título: The Sacred Book of the Werewolf
sinopsis: A supernatural call girl narrates Pelevin’s satirical allegory of post-Soviet, post-9/11 Russia.

Título: The School on Heart's Content Road
sinopsis: In Chute’s first novel in nearly 10 years, disparate characters cluster around an off-the-grid communal settlement.

Título: SIR GAWAIN AND THE GREEN KNIGHT: A New Verse Translation
sinopsis: One of the eerie, exuberant joys of Middle English poetry, in an alliterative rendering that captures the original’s drive, dialect and landscape.

Título: Sleeping It Off in Rapid City
sinopsis: Kleinzahler seeks the true heart of places, whether repellent, beautiful or both at once.
In this multilayered first novel, inter­national drifters try to bury pasts that include murder, adultery and neurotic meltdown, even as the Castro brothers gather revolutionaries in the hills.
This novel, first published in 1969, dovetails theme (the accidents of memory) with eccentric form (unbound chapters to be read in any order).

Título: When Will There Be Good News?
sinopsis: Jackson Brodie, the hero of Atkinson’s previous literary thrillers, takes the case of a mother and baby who suddenly disappear.
In this ingenious sequel to “The Witches of Eastwick,” the three title characters, old ladies now, renew their sisterhood, return to their old hometown and contrive to atone for past crimes.
Working-class Irish characters grapple with love, marriage, confusion and yearning in Enright’s varied, if somewhat disenchanted, stories.
Meacham, the editor of Newsweek, discerns a democratic dignity in the seventh president’s populism.
An engrossing portrait of Dick Cheney as a master political manipulator.

Título: Bacardi and the Long Fight for Cuba
sinopsis: An NPR correspondent paints a vivid portrait of the anti-Castro clan behind the liquor empire.

Autor: Bill Bishop con Robert G. Cushing
sinopsis: A journalist and a statistician see political dangers in the country’s increasing tendency to separate into solipsistic blocs.
Hard choices followed Gessen’s discovery that she carries a dangerous genetic mutation.
A collective biography of the pioneers of black political involvement.
An objective, thorough study of a landmark case for Guantánamo detainees.
Fischer argues that France’s North Ameri­can colonial success was attributable largely to one remarkable man, Samuel de Champlain.
Vieira de Mello, who was killed in Iraq in 2003, embodied both the idealism and the limitations of the United Nations, which he served long and loyally.
A New York Times reporter casts a keen eye on Rice’s tenure as a policy maker, her close ties to George Bush, and her personal and professional past.
Gioia’s survey balances the story of the music with that of its reception.
Shorto’s smart, elegant study turns the early separation of Descartes’s skull from the rest of his remains into an irresistible metaphor.
This fluent and intelligent book describes the struggles of people from Morocco to Iran to reform or replace long-entrenched national regimes.
This breezy crash course intersperses probabilistic mind-benders with profiles of theorists.

Título: An Exact Replica of a Figment of My Imagination
sinopsis: An unstinting account of the novelist’s emotions after the stillbirth of her first child.
Chang’s engrossing account delves deeply into the lives of young migrant workers in southern China.
Bass’s book is both a history and an argument for military interventions as a tool of international justice today.

Título: A Great Idea at the Time
sinopsis: The minds behind a curious project that continues to exert a hold in some quarters.
Adams’s wry, smart memoir stands with books by Hector Berlioz and Louis Armstrong among the most readably incisive autobiographies of major musical figures.
Gordon-Reed continues her study of the relationship between Sally Hemings and Thomas Jefferson.
The Times columnist turns his attention to possible business-friendly solutions to global warming.
Cooper, a New York Times reporter who fled a warring Liberia as a child, returned to confront the ghosts of her past — and to look for a lost sister.
Concentrating on the art of the novel, the New Yorker critic presents a compact, erudite vade mecum with acute observations on individual passages and authors.
Neiman champions Enlightenment values with no hint of over­simplification, dogmatism or misplaced piety.
Carr, a New York Times culture reporter, sifts through his drug- and alcohol-­addicted past.
Perlstein’s compulsively readable study holds that Nixon’s divisive and enduring legacy is the “notion that there are two kinds of Americans.”
The son of Soviet Tatars could never get enough of anything — space, applause, money, sex — but he attracted an audience of millions to the art form he mastered.
The best-picture nominees of 1967 were a collage of America’s psyche, and more.
This relentlessly intelligent examination of power focuses less on American decline than on the rise of China, trailed by India.
Moving comfortably from the lab to broad social questions to his own life, an M.I.T. economist pokes holes in conventional market theory.
Ford vivisects every sacred cow in “post-racist” America.
In this masterly account, Hastings describes Japanese madness eliciting American ruthlessness in the Pacific Theater.
A philosophy professor thinks our era has been too quick to dismiss religious faith.
With a polemicist’s vision and a scholar’s patience, Greer sets out to rescue Ann Hathaway from layers of biographical fantasy.

Autor: Bert Hölldobler y Edward O. Wilson
sinopsis: The central conceit of this astonishing study is that an insect colony is a single animal raised to a higher level.
A probing, conscientious account of strategy and tactics in post-surge Iraq.
A worthy history of the midcentury crusade against the comics industry.
A journalist traces the neoconservative movement from its origins at the City College of New York in the 1940s.
Searingly and unflinchingly, Blackburn describes an appalling upbringing at the hands of her catastrophically unfit parents.
Seymour’s odd and oddly affecting book instantly catapults her father into the front rank of impossible and eccentric English parents.
A surprising, enlightening look at the psychology of the human beings behind the steering wheels.
How we got into the mess we’re in, explained briefly and brilliantly.
An accessible popular history of early America, with plenty of self-tutoring and colorful reporting.
Reynolds excels at depicting the cultural, social and intellectual currents that buffeted the nation.
Harrison’s account brings moral clarity to the dark fate of the family of Jody Gilley, who was 16 when she survived a rampage by her brother in 1984.
The hitherto elusive Higginson was the poet’s chosen reader, admirer and advocate.
Macfarlane’s unorthodox British landscapes are furrowed with human histories and haunted by literary prophets.
Cohen’s middle-aged protagonist heads to Africa, leaving his wife back home in New England with a younger rival.
Meyer’s crime novel/road novel hybrid also manages to chronicle life in a dying mill town.
Baker’s ardent novel about poetry — with its hero trying, and mostly failing, to write an anthology introduction — actually does justice to poetry.
In midcentury Detroit, a young woman searches for authenticity and passion in art and in love.
A graphic novel 10 years in the making combines a modernist style, a formalist structure and a story about a bristly academic.
Three essentially separate story lines, with morbidly alienated main characters, link up at the end of Chaon’s unremittingly dark and provocative novel.
This clever novel’s Frankenstein hobnobs with the Shelleys.
An actor, saved from drowning by an unsavory rival, learns that gratitude never follows humiliation.
Gerstler’s poems — skillful in every kind of comedy, yet deeply serious — show a fondness for animals without sentimentalizing them.
The woes dramatized here are no less painful for being unexceptional.
Gaitskill implicates the reader in what feels like a violation of her own characters, whose lives are more often broken than in any way admirable.
This is the first English version of Fallada’s 1947 novel, based on a real-life German couple who mounted modest but suicidal resistance against Hitler.
This polished story collection takes its sustenance from class conflict, rough men and strong women, and the intersection between hotheads and cool customers.
It’s the slow, inexorable way everyone comes to acknowledge the suppressed event at the heart of this domestic novel that makes it quietly devastating.
A heroine bent on reinvention is at the center of this densely stitched crazy quilt of a novel, which spans six decades and a wealth of genres while evoking a quintessential American mythology.
This novel’s central figure is a woman ostensibly afflicted with hyperthymia — an excess of happiness.
This collection, from a career now reaching nearly three decades, reminds us how broad McInerney’s scope has been and how confidently he has ranged across our national experience.
The eight linked stories here follow the scheming of a rich and powerful Pakistani family and their employees.
The student-hero of Auster’s masterly novel learns about love from several characters, but an affair with his sister permanently defines his personality.

Título: Jeff in Venice, Death in Varanasi
sinopsis: This haunting novel is like a rough guide to transformation: moving from scenes of erotic decadence to scenes of squalor, the death it describes is that of craving, of intention, even of self.
This novel, about a boy’s memorable bonds with Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and Leon Trotsky, is a call to conscience and connection.
Phillips’s inspired novel, with its Faulknerian echoes, revolves around a loyal sister and her impaired brother, who sees what others don’t.
Philippe Petit’s 1974 high-wire walk between the twin towers is pivotal to all the lives in this deeply affecting New York novel.
In Waters’s novel of postwar anxiety, members of a decaying upper-crust English family start to come to sticky ends in their creepy mansion.
The worldly eccentric who narrates these tales declares a specialty in “those brainy postmodern setups” somehow tied to identity.
A heartbreaking and satisfying novel about the relationship between a restless amateur photographer and a shy young Irish farm wife.
The city of Istanbul is on exhibit in Pamuk’s novel of first love painfully sustained over a lifetime.
In his final collection of new fiction, Updike relives the matter of a lifetime and grapples with the effects of aging, disease and death.
First-person tales of human emotion in the waning hours of light.
Nelson is drawn to the damage that results when strong women foolishly trust weak men.
Elemental tales of lives on a South Korean island, in spare and beautiful prose.

Título: One D. O. A. , One on the Way
sinopsis: An angry heroine is thrust into the volatile world of her dying husband’s family, which includes his “utterly identical” twin.
Benji, the well-off 15-year-old black hero of Whitehead’s memoiristic fourth novel, lives in a world where life doesn’t assault him but rather affords him the time to figure out who he wants to be.
It’s hard not to be seduced by D’Erasmo’s selfish hero, an artist whose hunger for expression, for a father and for a home embodies a sense of entrapment that could make anyone behave badly.
Phillips turns the notion of the artistic muse on its head and gives it a spin, delineating a pas de deux between a young singer-songwriter and the older man who actively, obsessively inspires her.

Munro’s stories take on pulp fiction’s sensational subjects. But episodes of murder, suicide and adultery turn out to be just anterooms to an echo chamber filled with subtle and far-reaching thematic reverberations.
British and American spies clash in the buildup to the Beijing Olympics.
In a stylistic departure, Glück’s poems use the village as a lens to examine the lives within, which counterpoint the memories of her life without.
Tolerant, passionate and humane, Thomas Cromwell is cast as the picaresque hero of this Man Booker Prize-winning novel of Henry VIII’s turbulent court.
Through other mouths, Atwood has brilliantly retold her 2003 novel “Oryx and Crake,” showing how the kids Glenn and Jimmy became Crake and the Snowman.
Gilder’s book brings the reader into a mix of ideas and personalities, which she handles with verve.

Título: Ayn Rand and the World She Made
sinopsis: Heller maintains critical perspective while conveying the conviction and odd charisma of Rand, whose angry message resonates today among the anti-Obama right.
A memoir by The Times’s former restaurant critic, who writes of food, family, friendship and being fat.
Armstrong, a former nun, wants to rescue the idea of the Deity from its cultured despisers and its more literal-minded adherents alike.
This detailed biography follows John Cheever’s path step by stumbling step, disclosing the addictive urges and bawling self-pity to which he subjected himself and those in his household.
Friends and sheer perseverance got the novelist through his years of desire, poverty and thwarted ambition.
In Queenan’s account of his life, the belligerent priests, the poverty, the girls and the music all pale beside the rages of his drunken, violently abusive father.
From the physics of absolute zero to the cold-resistant gluttony of small birds, Streever reports on the extreme regions of low temperatures and the scientists who love them.
Cullen’s nuanced account anatomizes the massacre, showing how readily truth was obscured by myth.
How the 1840s paved the way to the Civil War.
This copious, lively history treats the game, and the qualities it demands, as characteristically American.
Dickstein demonstrates how glorious entertainments thrived in a decade of crisis.
An absorbing, well-researched and highly political biography of a transformative figure in modern photojournalism.
A grand, fascinating account of America’s first quarter-century, presented with great insight and scholarship.
In his careful yet provocative contemplation of religious history, Wright sees continuous positive moral change over time but denies the specialness of any individual faith.

Título: A Fiery Peace in a Cold War
sinopsis: Sheehan fully sets Schriever, a crucial figure behind the creation of America’s ICBM force, in the context of the cold war’s early years.
A Cambridge classics professor leads a fine tour, turning up surprises around every corner.
Stiles writes with care and panache about the quintessential “robber baron,” a man widely revered as well as hated.
Witty, obsessed and almost inhumanly brave, O’Connor was peculiar, her work even more so. But Gooch strives to make it all quite normal.
Ford tried and failed to build an ideal American society on an Amazonian rubber plantation.
A senior counsel to the 9/11 Commission assails the Bush administration’s depiction of the event as so much public relations flimflam.
Not dwelling on Barthelme’s dark soul or his uneven work, Daugherty has created a convincing narrative from a life that was engaged, passionate and maybe even fulfilled.
An uplifting account of how Special Forces soldiers joined with mounted local militias to beat back the Taliban in 2001.
A hair-raising tale of the race to stave off a depression.
A satisfying genre-blending consideration of Joseph Priestley and his fertile ideas.
Pakula’s often absorbing biography presents Madame Chiang as far more complicated, awful and brilliant than we had imagined.
In its moments of real ambivalence, this loving and funny filial memoir of Bill and Pat Buckley is surprisingly strong drink.
Myerson interweaves powerful scenes of her son’s drug addiction with the story of a young consumptive who died in 1838.
Grann follows the trail of the English adventurer/explorer Percy Fawcett, who disappeared in 1925.
The witty, self-castigating story of how Kirn’s schooling left him “not so much educated as wised up.”
An admiring biography of the Supreme Court justice as a reformer and legal innovator.
Romm’s fury over her mother’s cancer is magnetic, with the power to both repel and attract, and here it is transformed into an instrument for pursuing truth.
In his unnerving portrait of Oelwein, Iowa, Reding depicts a catastrophe of Chernobylish dimensions, precipitated by the loss of jobs and the rise of methamphetamines.
Evans was a large part of the era of British newspapers he describes, when journalists were literate buccaneers.

Título: The Myth of the Rational Market
sinopsis: In this essential account, Fox zeroes in on the academics whose efficient-market theories enabled abuses.
Bracingly devoid of triumphalist homily, Agassi’s is one of the most passionately anti-sports books ever written by a superstar athlete.
A powerful work that offers an impassioned challenge to the social meaning of disasters.
Along with athletic ability, showmanship helped make Satchel Paige the most lasting symbol of black baseball.
Much credit for success goes to Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.
An encomium to manual skills, by a political philosophy Ph.D. who can rebuild VW engines.
The quantum pioneer had an almost miraculous apprehension of the physical world, coupled with an innocent incomprehension of other people.
A superbly textured, compassionate biography.
This riveting final volume to Evans’s magisterial trilogy illuminates the endless human capacity for evil and self-justification.

Título: The Weight of a Mustard Seed
sinopsis: This elegantly told story weaves together the Iraqi past and present.
A Times columnist’s thorough, smart and often wry account of American women’s strides and the hurdles they still face.
The Brazilian writer was born to remorse, shaken by trauma and imbued with a deep sense of alienation.
Roosevelt, as shown in this vast, energetic book, saw conservation as crucial to America’s military and moral standing.
A sense of urgency runs through this disturbing exploration of the motives and actions that have led to mass murder.
Mallon’s fine meditation on the art of letter-writing embraces old friends — Flaubert, Freud, the Mitfords — and plenty of unknowns as well.
This suspenseful nonfiction account of what happened to a Syrian-American man and his family after Hurricane Katrina is a powerful indictment of Bush-era policies.
A bombing unites a blogger and a beautiful eco-terrorist in this literary thriller, an exploration of what motivates radicalism in an age of disillusion.

With a smitten art historian at her side, the young nun at the center of this rousing first novel is drawn into an ancient struggle against the Nephilim, hybrid offspring of humans and heavenly beings.
A deeply cynical academic fund-raiser fighting for his job is the protagonist of this darkly humorous satire, a witty paean to white-collar loserdom.
For Nelson’s complacent heroine, the death of an estranged friend elicits memories of their reckless youth.
Set in Nazi-occupied Europe, this novel, appearing only now in English, is a mid-century masterpiece by the centenarian Keilson, who served in the Dutch resistance.
Hughes likes to juxtapose her characters’ relative passivity with the knife edge of evil within or, more often, outside them.

This nimble, entertaining homage to Henry James’s late work “The Ambassadors,” in which an American heads to Paris to retrieve a wayward son, brilliantly upends the theme, meaning and stylistic manner of its revered precursor.
Our enduring central struggle — the battle between the head and the heart — is enacted again and again in Stone’s collection.

Título: Girl by the Road at Night
sinopsis: In this tale of war and eros, two young people from opposite ends of the earth are caught up in events far beyond their control.

Título: The Girl Who Kicked The Hornet's Nest
sinopsis: In the third installment of the pulse-racing trilogy featuring Mikael Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander, the pair are threatened by an adversary from deep within the very government that should be protecting them.
In this tragic vision of a novel, Nadia, a writer in New York, faces a wrenching parting when a girl shows up to claim an enormous desk that has been in her safekeeping for decades.

Título: How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe
sinopsis: Yu wraps his lonely story of a time machine repairman in layers of gorgeous meta-science-fiction.
Mengestu’s own origins inform this tale of an Ethiopian-American tracing the uncertain road once taken by his parents.

Título: I Curse the River of Time
sinopsis: This novel’s lonely Scandinavian protagonist grapples with divorce, death and the fall of the Berlin Wall.
A murder mystery punctuated with serious philosophical musings, this novel traces 150 years of Filipino history, posing questions about identity and art, exile and duty.
This intricate novel is built around the personal stories of staff members at an improbable English-language newspaper in Rome, and of the family who founded it in the 1950s.
Orringer’s protagonist is a Jewish architecture student in late-1930s Paris forced to return home to Hungary ahead of the Nazi invasion there.
In these intellectual poems, the experimental curtains suddenly part to reveal clear, durable truth.
Hirsch’s “living fire” is an irrational counterforce with which he balances his dignified quotidian.
Levy’s high-spirited, ambitious heroine works on a plantation in the final days of slavery in Jamaica.

Título: The Lost Books of the Odyssey
sinopsis: The conceit behind the multiple Odysseuses here (comic, dead, doubled, amnesiac) is that this is a translation of an ancient papyrus, a collection of variations on the myth.
The photojournalist heroine of Soli’s Vietnam War novel ponders whether those who represent war merely replicate its violence.
In this tale, 30 years in the creation, bloody folly envelops a Marine company’s construction, abandonment and retaking of a remote hilltop outpost.
These strange, beautiful stories all ask: What, if anything, will be spared time’s depredations?
In this daring first novel, a computer game designer suspected of murdering his obese wife is investigated by two marriage-savvy detectives, one of whom is Dr. Sam Sheppard.
The C.I.A. spy in this thriller is sick of his trade’s duplicity, amorality and rootlessness.
Nicholls’s nostalgic novel checks in year by year on the halting romance of two children of the ’80s, she an outspoken lefty, he an apolitical toff.
In this contemporary morality tale, a family stumbles along, rich and dysfunctional, without ethical or moral responsibility.
In this nuanced literary thriller, a deal to acquire Soviet-era cultural artifacts puts a Parisian clothing designer and her filmmaker husband in peril.
Erdrich’s portrait of a marriage on its way to dissolution appears to be seeded with deliberate allusions to her own relationship with the writer Michael Dorris.
McEwan’s funniest novel yet, a self-deluding physicist cheats on his wives, sends an innocent man to jail and tries to cash in on another scientist’s plans against global warming.
Gilmore’s contemplative second novel explores the lost ideals and lingering illusions of a family once politically committed to bettering the world.
Oates explores the idea that the bereaved wife is a kind of guilty party who deserves everything — most of it violent — that comes her way.
Like Beckett, Means reveals a God-like inclination to see his characters as forsaken case studies.
Exhilarating prose illuminates the horrors of a future America in this satire.
As death draws near, Lee’s heroine, a Korean War orphan now living in New York, sets off for Europe to look for her estranged son.

Título: The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet
sinopsis: Mitchell’s historical novel about a young Dutchman in Edo-era Japan is an achingly romantic story of forbidden love and something of an adventurous rescue tale.
Two Manhattan sisters, one wildly emotional, one smartly sensible, come to the aid of their beloved aging mother.

Título: To the End of the Land
sinopsis: Two friends are deeply involved with the same woman in this somber, haunting novel of love and loyalty in time of conflict, set in Israel between 1967 and 2000.
Engel’s understated stories are told from the perspective of a daughter of Colombian immigrants.
Though the characters in her harrowing fourth collection buckle under the weight of misfortune, Kennedy can go from darkness to humor in a heartbeat.
The Nobel Prize winner’s latest collection is intensely personal, an old man’s book, craving one more day of light and warmth.
In these tales, Boyle continues his career-long interest in man’s vexed tussles with nature.
More than offering a backward look, this account of the disaster of 2008 helps explain today’s troubling headlines and might help predict tomorrow’s.
A colorful, emotional argument that 2008 gave feminism a thrilling “new life.”
A thought-provoking revisionist history of the early years of printing.
This study of Obama before he became president, by the editor of The New Yorker, has many important additions and corrections to make to our reading of “Dreams From My Father.”
The quirky pleasures here are due in part to Smith’s inspired cultural references, from Simone Weil to “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.”
The urbane presentation of Earl Derr Biggers’s fictional Chinese sleuth, in print and in film, ran counter to the racism of his era.
The final volume of Morris’s monumental life of Theodore Roosevelt vividly covers the eventful nine years after he left office.
Hyde draws on the American founders for arguments against the privatization of knowledge.
Shapiro is particularly interested in what “the authorship question” says about successive generations of readers.
Hessler chronicles the effects of an expanding road network on the rapidly changing lives of individual Chinese.
The story of the last and greatest chief of the tribe that once ruled the Great Plains.
Foner tackles what would seem an obvious topic, Lincoln and slavery, and sheds new light on it.
Even as Greenberg lays out the grim and complicated facts about the ravaging of our seas, he manages to sound some hopeful notes about the ultimate fate of fish.
MacCulloch traces the faith’s history through classical philosophy and Jewish tradition, fantastical visions and cold calculations, loving sacrifices and imperial ambitions.
When the colorful, prolific journalist shares a tender memory, he quickly converts it into a larger observation about politics, always for him the most crucial sphere of moral and intellectual life.

A philosopher traces the demise of dueling and slavery among the British and of foot-binding in China, and suggests how a fourth horrific practice — honor killings in today’s Pakistan — might someday meet its end.
Illuminating essays on the arts in the context of a “post art” era.

Título: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
sinopsis: Skloot untangles the ethical issues in the case of a woman who unknowingly donated cancer cells that have been the basis for a vast amount of research.
In this beautifully written, slyly humorous encyclopedia, Raffles seeks to redress the speciesism that has cast insects as creatures to be regarded with distrust and disgust.
Scammell wants to put the complex intelligence of Koestler (“Darkness at Noon”) back on display and to explain his shifting preoccupations.
Many biographies of Mantle have been written, but Leavy connects the dots in new and disturbing ways.
A remarkably original account of the 14-year orgy of lawbreaking that transformed American social life.
Amid all the racism, Aaron approached his pursuit of Babe Ruth’s home run record more as grim chore than joyous mission.
The author of “Mayflower” gives appropriate space to Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse and others who fought that day, but Custer steals the show.
Reading Richards’s autobiography is like getting to corner him in a room to ask everything you always wanted to know about the Rolling Stones.
The English gerontologist Aubrey de Grey, a proselytizer for radical life extension, is the main figure in this engaging study.
In these graceful essays, the neurologist explores how his patients compensate for the abilities they have lost, and confronts his own ocular cancer.
An entertaining spy tale about the British ruse that employed a corpse to cover up the invasion of Sicily.
Paul’s balanced, common-sense inquiry into the emerging field of fetal origins research is structured around her own pregnancy.
This series of character studies — some of familiar figures, some not — is arranged to give meaning to a volatile, complicated city.
The vast historical backdrop of this biography informs but never overwhelms its remarkable, elusive subject.
This biography maintains that discomfort with Armstrong’s public persona has led detractors to minimize his enormous contributions to music and to civilization.
An entertaining memoir-cum-travelogue of a graduate student’s improbable education in Russian language and literature.

Harman surveys 150 years of scientific history to examine the theoretical problem at the core of behavioral biology, sociobiology and evolutionary psychology: Why do organisms sacrifice themselves for the benefit of others?
This appraisal by a Newsweek columnist is mercifully free of the sensationalistic tone of other recent campaign books.
The creator of Time and Life used his magazines to advance political favorites, paint an uplifting portrait of the middle class and promote American intervention in the world.
Maier’s history lays out the major issues, the arguments, the local context, the major and minor players, and lots of political rough stuff.
This wide-ranging meditation is part spiritual memoir, part religious history, part literary exegesis.
A group portrait of Felix Frankfurter, Robert Jackson, Hugo Black and William O. Douglas.
A sad, dangerous, astonishingly eccentric 20th-century life, recounted in absorbing detail.
Contention over Roosevelt’s proposal to transform the court nearly paralyzed his administration for over a year and severely damaged fragile Democratic unity.
A witty biography of the manipulative, secretive and obsessive creator of Tom Ripley, a character who was a version of Highsmith herself.
A journey along a latitude line where two religions meet and often clash.
Dubious meals, vehicle malfunctions and relics of the Gulag fill Frazier’s uproarious, sometimes dark account of his wanderings.
Chernow brings his considerable literary talent to bear on the continued hunger of many Americans for more tales of the first president’s exploits.
Brainy scientists, extreme surfers and mountains of water mix it up in Casey’s vivid, kinetic narrative.
In his long, fascinating account, Hirsch concentrates mostly on the baseball brilliance, reminding us of a time when the only performance-enhancing drug was joy.
This voluminous novel, set in 1984, is simultaneously a mystery, a love story and a dystopian fantasy that raises questions of psychology and ethics.
DeLillo’s first collection of short fiction, compiling stories written between 1979 and 2011, serves as a liberating reminder that terror existed long before there was a war on it.
A big, insightful novel about social and ethnic conflict in contemporary Los Angeles.

Título: BIG QUESTIONS. Or, Asomatognosia: Whose Hand Is It Anyway?
sinopsis: In this capacious, metaphysically inclined graphic novel, a flock of finches act out Nilsen’s unsettling comic vision about the food chain, fate and death.
Through a chorus of narrators, Otsuka unfurls the stories of Japanese women who came to America in the early 1900s to marry men they’d never met.
With this English translation, Leopardi may at last become as important to American literature as Rilke or Baudelaire.
Ondaatje grants that this novel, about three daring Ceylonese schoolboys on a sea journey to England, sometimes uses the “coloring and locations of memoir.”
In Kennedy’s most musical work of fiction, a newspaperman attains a cynical old-pro objectivity as Albany’s political machine pulls out the stops to head off a race riot in 1968.
Much of the poetry here, displaying a consistent stillness and confidence, is the strongest of Zapruder’s career.
This nearly 1,200-page novel opens in 1989 and is centered, roughly, on a Budapest apartment building whose residents have been trapped in the torpor of Communist tyranny.
Bezmozgis overturns clichéd expectations of immigrant idealism in his first novel, which follows a Soviet Jewish family awaiting visas in Rome in 1978.
Millet sends an I.R.S. agent on a mission to a Central American jungle, providing a fascinating glimpse of what can happen when the self’s rhythms and certainties are shaken.
Complex but fundamentally decent characters hurt one another and are hurt by forces greater than themselves, as a family sinks beneath the weight of a terrible secret.
Beneath the shadowless Norman Rockwell contours of Baxter’s Midwest lurks a chilling starkness and sense of isolation reminiscent of the bleakly beautiful work of Edward Hopper.
Hilarious and extremely dirty, this episodic assortment of fantasies — part Plato’s Retreat, part Fantasy Island — celebrates desire, frailty and the comedy of life.
A wry, world-weary and hyper-articulate werewolf, morally as well as physically ambiguous, is tortured by the spirits of his victims and ready to surrender to his pursuers.
In this novelistic version of the biblical prophecy known as the Rapture, Hindus, Buddhists and Muslims as well as Christians mysteriously disappear.
Smith’s impressive range is on full display in her third poetry collection, in which she mourns her father, who worked on the Hubble Telescope.
Hadley’s artfully constructed, socially realistic novel is split between two characters who react in opposite ways to their old affair.
Hannah, who died last year, had a refined eye for the outrageous; this collection shows he retained full command of his powers to the end of his life.
This novel, about a paroled sex offender, bravely tries to find humanity in people whom society often despises.
Eugenides adeptly renders the patter of college intellectuals and the sweet banter of courtship, and is particularly astute on the uncertainties awaiting after graduation.
Sayles’s reimagining of America at the turn of the last century nods to both Harriet Beecher Stowe and Thomas Pynchon.
This playful tale is presented in the alternating voices of a slasher novelist, his wife and his muse, the last of whom urges the writer to embrace intimacy over violence and death.
Prose’s sardonic novel of a young Albanian immigrant in New Jersey sets Ameri­ca in high relief, mordant and comic, light and dark.
The peripatetic hero of Cole’s indelible novel reflects on his adopted New York, the Africa of his youth, today’s America and a Europe wary of its future.
Unfolding on an epic scale, this coherent, if uncompleted, portrayal of our age is a grand parable of “late capitalism,” set in the innards of the Internal Revenue Service.
Goldman’s passionate, moving narrative takes as its subject his tragically short marriage to the writer Aura Estrada, who died in a bodysurfing accident in 2007, when she was 30.
In these powerful linked stories of longing and disappointment, Oz returns to a spare, almost allegorical style.
In this Booker Prize winner, an unexpected bequest forces a man to re-evaluate his relationships, present and past.
Stamm’s protagonist, an aspiring architect in 1980s Germany, wanders between his charming, frigid wife and plain but devoted mistress.
The Bosnian hero of Prcic’s absorbing and unsettling first novel is shattered by war.
What may be the most ambitious, and disturbing, of Kasischke’s eight books of poems strives to comprehend first and last things.
A faded heroine struggles with the loss of her brother, an unrecognized rock star, in this acerbic and deeply sad narrative.
Hollinghurst’s sharply drawn novel tells the story of relatives and scholars grappling with the legacy of a Rupert Brooke-like poet killed during World War I.
This resonant and darkly comic novel, by a former New York Times journalist, imagines an uproar over a proposed Sept. 11 memorial.
Viscerally smoldering anger, the signature quality of Murray’s poetry, turns conventional pieties inside out.
A family’s Manhattan life comes apart when their 15-year-old forwards a sexually explicit video made for him, unsolicited, by a girl two years younger.
Phillips’s splendidly devious novel consists of a Shakespearean play of his own virtuosic creation and an “introduction” that devastatingly reveals the psychological life of its author.
The taming of the American West is encompassed in Johnson’s novella, whose orphaned hero is sent by train in the 1890s into the woods of the Idaho panhandle.
This follow-up to “1491” argues that ecological encounters since Columbus have shaped much of subsequent human history.
In this account of the war’s first stage, Goodheart turns his lens upon fascinating figures who loomed large at the time but have now been mostly forgotten.
A young composer’s account of his cancer sidesteps the issue of sentimentality by mocking it, in prose bright and jazzy and meandering.

From Dresden to his mother’s suicide, the early death of a beloved sister, serial unhappy marriages and literary anxiety, Vonnegut earned his status as Man of Sorrows, as this diligent and often heartbreaking biography shows.
Nelson examines representations of violence in the media, largely aiming her laments high up the cultural ladder — at the fine arts, literature, theater and even poetry.
In gripping style, Hakakian recounts the 1992 killings of four Iranian opposition members in Berlin, which ultimately implicated the top levels of Iran’s leadership.
Deutsch’s inexhaustibly curious exploration of the nature and progress of knowledge pivots on the European Enlightenment.
The filmmaker is chiefly interested here in the nature of knowledge, in figuring out where the truth lies.

Título: The Better Angels of Our Nature
sinopsis: Are humans essentially good or bad? Has the past century seen moral progress or moral collapse? Pinker addresses these questions and more.
This memoir by the chef at the Manhattan restaurant Prune is a story of hungers specific and vague.
Mourning the 2005 death of her daughter, Didion presents herself as defenseless against the pain of loss in this elegantly written memoir.
Caravaggio’s painting was deeply affected by the squalor, violence and energy of Roman street life.
Massie provides a sweeping narrative about the impressive minor German princess who became empress of Russia.
In this biography, Darrow’s unsavory side is on view, from his personal callousness to his purchasing of testimony.

Título: Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness
sinopsis: Fuller’s mother is the star of this funny and affecting memoir, a companion to “Don’t Let’s Go to the Dogs Tonight.”
A deranged man shot James Garfield, but it was his incompetent doctors who killed him.
Lethem’s extraliterary enthusiasms are all over this hefty collection, which includes essays on film, comics, music, Brooklyn and, of course, fiction.
Miller shows philosophers becoming ever more inclined to reflect on their own petty failings, and suggests this makes their lives more, not less, worth studying.
Gaddis has written a magisterial biography of the man who both invented the cold war policy of containment and was one of its most perspicacious critics.
While many of Gandhi’s aspirations (a Muslim-Hindu alliance, a full end to untouchability) remain largely unfulfilled, it is his role as a social reformer that most interests Lelyveld.
A Harlem transplant documents her own and others’ experiences there, working not to define the neighborhood, but to revise received ideas.
The Portuguese explorer hoped to find Christians in India and enlist them in an alliance against Islam.
The experiences of the ambassador William E. Dodd and his lusty daughter, Martha.

Hastings has a sober, unromantic and realistic view of battle that puts him in a different category from the armchair generals whose gung-ho attitude to war fills the pages of so many military histories.
Gleick argues that information is more than just the contents of our libraries and Web servers: human consciousness, life on earth, the cosmos — it’s bits all the way down.
Reitman has rendered the most complete picture of Scientology so far.

Título: Is That a Fish in Your Ear?
sinopsis: Against the orthodox view that a translation can’t substitute for the original, a scholar argues that the two need not be the same, but only similar.
Three thousand years, packed with telling detail, in the life of the holy city.
A Stanford professor’s clever pairing of the lives of the poet Keats and his brother, who emigrated to the American backcountry.
A Harvard professor meditates on the nature of science and where physics is headed.
Before Judt died last year of a disease that left him clearheaded but immobile, he dictated these vivid autobiographical sketches, the best of which recall life in his native England.
One of America’s most troubling historical figures is the subject of Horwitz’s deft narrative.
Where those rubber toys came from, where they drifted, and why.
The international calypso star, actor and mainstay of the civil rights movement recalls his life.
In this challenging and often contrarian book, Morozov explores how the Internet is used to constrict or even abolish political freedom.

Título: One Day I Will Write About This Place
sinopsis: The author describes fiction as his refuge from the confusing realities of politics and adolescence in his native Kenya.
What countries are capable of “getting to Denmark”? Fukuyama’s answer emphasizes the role of contingency.
Kellow’s is a fair-minded and deeply reported biography of the provocative and maddening writer whose essays about movies transformed American pop-culture criticism.
These thrumming, intelligent magazine essays highlight Sullivan’s interest in the rare cultural nexus where genuine artistry intersects with commercial popularity.
This comprehensive study makes clear that energy policy is not on the right course anywhere.

The Stanford professor argues that the progressive left and the colorblind right are guilty of the same error: defining discrimination too abstractly and condemning it too categorically, with similarly perverse results.
How the soulful German shepherd, born on a World War I battlefield, conquered Hollywood and became a family­friendly symbol of cold war gunslinging.
In a clear, accessible account of the war in all its theaters, Roberts asks how the Wehr­macht, the best fighting force, wound up losing.
The legacy of the Roman poet Lucretius, and the Renaissance book hunter who saved his great poem from oblivion.
Weighed down by grief after the death of his mother, the author makes a pilgrimage to Mount Kailas, venerated by Hindus, Buddhists, Jains and others.
This stirring account concentrates on the appalling losses in the ranks and on the courage of those who decided the war in Europe was not a just one.
Moorehead meticulously traces the fates of 230 Frenchwomen sent to Auschwitz as political prisoners of the Reich.

Autor: Steven Naifeh y Gregory White Smith
sinopsis: Was Van Gogh a high-I.Q. aesthete or an earnest simpleton? A frugal bohemian or a big spender? A man who took his own life or a man who was murdered? This hulking and energetic biography complicates the picture.
The author’s interviews with 105 prominent African-Americans suggest that today’s “black identity” has cleared the way to a liberating pursuit of individuality.

Título: Why the West Rules - For Now
sinopsis: A Stanford historian argues that we face an immediate choice — East-West cooperation or catastrophe.
A young hacker on the run in the Mideast is the protagonist of this imaginative first novel.
In this glorious satire of machismo, a Mexican agronomist simultaneously pursues a prostitute and an upright woman.
In a novel vividly evoking the multilayered world of espionage, Steinhauer’s hero fights back when his C.I.A. unit is nearly destroyed.
Groff’s lush and visual second novel begins at a rural commune, and links that utopian past to a dystopian, post-global-warming future.
The final and most meditative of St. Aubyn’s brilliant Patrick Melrose novels is full of precise observations and glistening turns of phrase.
Walter’s witty sixth novel, set largely in Hollywood, reveals an American landscape of vice, addiction, loss and disappointed hopes.
The survivors of a fierce firefight in Iraq are whisked stateside for a brief victory tour in this satirical novel.
The best stories in Alexie’s collection of new and selected works are moving and funny, bringing together the embittered critic and the yearning dreamer.
Jewish immigrant lives observed with effusive nostalgia.
This smart, slippery novel is a narrative striptease, as a professor listens in on the sessions between the therapist next door and her patients.
A boy whose parents rob a bank in North Dakota in 1960 takes refuge across the border in this mesmerizing novel, driven by fully realized characters and an accomplished prose style.
Anshaw pays close attention to the lives of a group of friends bound together by a fatal accident in this wry, humane novel, her fourth.

Somewhere in Ireland in 2053, people are haunted by a “lost time,” when something calamitous happened, and hope to reclaim the past. Barry’s extraordinary, exuberant first novel is full of inventive language.
In orderly free verse constructions, Gilbert deals plainly with grief, love, marriage, betrayal and lust.
This volume offers further proof of Munro’s mastery, and shows her striking out in the direction of a new, late style that sums up her whole career.
LaValle’s culturally observant third novel is set in a shabby urban mental hospital.
Harrison’s splendid and surprising novel of late imperial Russia centers on Rasputin’s daughter Masha and the hemophiliac ­czarevitch Alyosha.
An Appalachian woman becomes involved in an effort to save monarch butterflies in this brave and majestic novel.
Clerks, cooks and lawyers at a forward operating base in Iraq populate this first novel.
In Soli’s haunting second novel, a mysterious Caribbean woman cares for a cancer patient on an isolated California ranch.
Three generations of black women confront floods and murder in Mississippi.
Related stories, spanning centuries and continents, and all tethered to a desert rock formation, emphasize interconnectivity across time and space in Kunzru’s relentlessly modern fourth novel.
This gripping novel examines both the killing of an SS general in Prague in 1942 and Binet’s experience in writing about it.
A black Korean War veteran, discharged from an integrated Army into a segregated homeland, makes a reluctant journey back to Georgia in a novel engaged with themes that have long haunted Morrison.
Hilarity alternates with pain in this novel about a Jewish man seeking peace in upstate New York who discovers Anne Frank in his ­attic.
The narrator (also named Sheila) and her friends try to answer the question in this novel’s title.
Irving’s funny, risky new novel about an aspiring writer struggling with his sexuality examines what happens when we face our desires honestly.

Título: A Land More Kind Than Home
sinopsis: An evil pastor dominates Cash’s mesmerizing first novel.
Hadley’s understatedly beautiful collection is filled with exquisitely calibrated gradations and expressions of class.

Título: On the Spectrum of Possible Deaths
sinopsis: Taut, lucid poems filled with complex emotional reflection.
Children battle for the planet’s redemption in this precisely written postapocalyptic adventure story.
A dark, magisterial novel set on a Chesapeake Bay estate.
In this novel, an American Indian family faces the ramifications of a vicious crime.
A pregnant 15-year-old and her family await Hurricane Katrina in this lushly written novel.
Two utopians from different eras establish private idylls on California’s desolate Channel Islands; this novel preserves their tantalizing dreams.
This thought-provoking debut novel presents a geeky astronaut and his pregnant wife.
The stories in Serber’s first collection are smart and nuanced.
A family is a microcosm of a country on the verge of a coup in this intense, foreboding novel, first published in Turkey in 1983.
Dermont’s captivating debut novel, whose narrator is a boarding school student and a sailor, takes pleasure in the sea and in the exhilarating freedom of being young.
The true subject of this smart and tricky novel, set inside a cold war espionage operation, is the border between make-believe and reality.
In this spare, disturbing and frequently funny novel, a troubled young woman tests the marriages of two couples.
Chabon’s rich comic novel about fathers and sons in Berkeley and Oakland, Calif., juggles multiple plots and mounds of pop culture references in astonishing prose.
This beautiful work takes power from the surprises of its language and its almost shocking characterization of Mary, mother of Jesus.

Título: This Is How You Lose Her
sinopsis: The stories in this collection are about love, but they’re also about the undertow of family history and cultural mores, presented in Díaz’s exciting, irresistible and entertaining prose.
In loosely linked narratives, three women from Senegal struggle with fathers and husbands in France. This subtle, hypnotic novel won the Prix Goncourt in 2009.
This novel, a sequel to “Life Class,” delves further into the lives of an English family torn apart by World War I.
This novelistic re­imagining of the “third-rate burglary” proposes surprising motives for the break-in and the 18-minute gap, and has a sympathetic Nixon.

Título: What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank
sinopsis: Englander tackles large questions of morality and history in a masterly collection that manages to be both insightful and ­uproarious.
The vanished world of midcentury upper-class lesbians is portrayed as beguiling, its inhabitants members of a stylish club.
A Times reporter’s deeply researched chronicle of several generations of Mrs. Obama’s family.
The author evokes an era when the game was more vivid and less corporate than it seems now.
Bechdel’s engaging, original graphic memoir explores her troubled relationship with her distant mother.
This huge and absorbing new biography, full of previously unexplored detail, shows that Obama’s saga is more surprising and gripping than the version we’re familiar with.
The fascinating tale of the 19th-century Italian monk, a “notorious tomb robber,” who gathered archaeological treasures in Egypt while crunching bones underfoot.
The first Alexandre Dumas, a mixed-race general of the French Revolution, is the subject of this imaginative biography.
Williams’s environmental call to arms deplores chemicals in breast milk and the vogue for silicone implants.
The author of “The Bell Curve” warns that the white working class has abandoned the “founding virtues.”
Stott’s lively, original history of evolutionary ideas flows easily across continents and centuries.
The author’s ancestor was the bane of Ulysses S. Grant.
Carpenter stirringly describes the 2003 Supreme Court decision that overturned the Texas sodomy law.
An intriguing argument that deceit is a beneficial evolutionary “deep feature” of life.
A poet’s lively account of the central place of the trickster figure in black American culture could have been called “How Blacks Invented America.”
Foreign meddling, the lack of a democratic tradition, a humiliating American occupation and cold-war support of a brutal dictator all figure in a scholar’s well-written analysis.
Noncognitive skills like persistence and self-control are more crucial to success than sheer brainpower, Tough maintains.
This guidebook also explores the eccentric rock star’s personal and professional experience.
An overwhelming and convincing account of the Soviet push to colonize Eastern Europe after World War II.
This thoughtful meditation on the evolution of grief over time asks the big questions.
A tension between humanitarianism and righteousness has shaped America’s rules of warfare.
A beautifully written and deeply reported account of America’s troubled involvement in ­Afghanistan.
A feminist scholar recounts her experience and criticizes the medical treatment of a frightening disease in a voice that is straightforward and incredibly brave.
Part memoir and part criticism, this friendly book includes essays on poets canonical and contemporary, as well as lineated poem-games.
Michelle Obama sets the tone and tempo of the current White House, Kantor argues in this admiring account, full of colorful insider anecdotes.
A Times reporter’s deeply affecting account of his son’s coming out also reviews research on the experience of LGBT kids.
An absorbing biography of the pioneering environmental writer on the 50th anniversary of “Silent Spring.”
A Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist unveils this inscrutable country, comparing its calcified regime to the Soviet Union in its final days.
Smith argues that Brown was the most significant modern American musician in terms of style, messaging, rhythm and originality.
An evenhanded investigation of a murder.

Título: Red Brick, Black Mountain, White Clay
sinopsis: Mixing memoir, family saga, travelogue and cultural ­history.
Pragmatic Republicanism was hardier than we remember, Kabaservice argues.
A gripping and revelatory biography of the eminent cartoonist.
An uninhibited and learned account of the attempts on the life of Queen Victoria, which only increased her popularity.

Título: Short Nights of the Shadow Catcher
sinopsis: A deft portrait of the man who made memorable photographs of American ­Indians.
The evolutionary biologist explores the strange kinship between humans and some insects.
The South African novelist and playwright absorbingly illuminates his wide, worldly life.
Quammen’s meaty, sprawling book chronicles his globe-trotting scientific adventures and warns against animal microbes spilling over into people.
Collingham argues that food needs contributed to the war’s origins, strategy, outcome and aftermath.
This readable and well-researched life celebrates Jefferson’s skills as a practical politician, unafraid to wield power even when it conflicted with his small-government views.
Written with knowing finesse, this expansive history of gay rights from the early 20th century to the present draws on archives and interviews.
Evangelicals believe that God speaks to them personally because they hone the skill of prayer, this insightful study argues.

Título: Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal?
sinopsis: Winterson’s unconventional and winning memoir wrings humor from adversity as it describes her upbringing by a wildly deranged mother.
Oates’s extravagantly horrifying, funny and prolix postmodern Gothic novel purports to be the definitive account of a curse that infected bucolic Princeton, N.J., in 1905 and 1906.

Salter’s first novel in more than 30 years, which follows the loves and losses of a World War II veteran, is an ambitious departure from his previous work and, at a stroke, demolishes any talk of twilight.
Airliners crash not only into the twin towers but into a shaggy-dog tale involving a fraud investigator and a white-collar outlaw in this vital, audacious novel.
The adventure-seeking protagonist of Hoagland’s novel is swept up in the chaos of southern Sudan.
In a disturbing not-too-distant future, human existence flows through the portal of a company that gives Eggers’s novel its title.
Danticat’s novel is less about a Haitian girl who disappears on her birthday than about the heart of a magical seaside village.
Physical objects help Bender’s characters grasp an overwhelming world.
Odds against survival are high for the characters of Marra’s extraordinary first novel, set in war-torn Chechnya.
In this clever, dark Dutch novel, two couples dine out under the cloud of a terrible crime committed by their teenage sons.
Four linked stories expose their characters’ bottomless needs and stubborn weaknesses.
Spanning 80 years and three generations, Lethem’s novel realistically portrays an enchanted — or disenchanted — garden of American leftists in Queens.
Now grown up, Danny, the boy with psycho-intuitive powers in “The Shining,” helps another threatened magic child in a novel that shares the virtues of King’s best work.
A schoolteacher takes an unusual lover in this astonishing, double-hinged novel set in a fantastical suburbia.
A summer house on the Massachusetts coast both shelters and isolates the wealthy family in Graver’s eloquent multigenerational novel.

McBride’s romp of a novel, the 2013 National Book Award winner, is narrated by a freed slave boy who passes as a girl. It’s a risky portrait of the radical abolitionist John Brown in which irreverence becomes a new form of ­homage.
Ausubel’s fantastical collection traces a cycle of transformation: from love to conception to gestation to birth.
In Segal’s darkly comic novel, dementia becomes contagious at a Manhattan hospital.

Título: I Want to Show You More
sinopsis: Quatro’s strange, thrilling and disarmingly honest first collection draws from a pool of resonant themes (Christianity, marital infidelity, cancer, running) in agile ­recombinations.

Título: The Impossible Lives of Greta Wells
sinopsis: A distraught woman inhabits different selves across the 20th century in Greer’s elegiac novel.
Amid a proliferation of alternative perspectives, Marías’s novel explores its female narrator’s relationship with the widow and the best friend of a murdered man.
Wolitzer’s enveloping novel offers a fresh take on the theme of self-invention, with a heroine who asks herself whether the ambitious men and women in her circle have inaccurately defined success.
This triptych, set in Gurganus’s familiar Falls, N.C., showcases the increasing universality of his imaginative powers.
Baker’s charming novel offers an affecting look at the world of “Pride and Prejudice” from the point of view of the Bennets’ servants’ hall.

Título: Love, Dishonor, Marry, Die; Cherish, Perish
sinopsis: Rakoff completed his novel-in-couplets, whose characters live the title’s verbs, just before his death in 2012.
After his radical brother is killed, an Indian scientist brings his widow to join him in America in Lahiri’s efficiently written novel.
In her Booker Prize winner, a love story and mystery set in New Zealand, Catton has built a lively parody of a 19th-century novel, while creating something utterly new for the 21st.
The survivors of “Oryx and Crake” and “The Year of the Flood” await a final showdown, in a trilogy’s concluding entry.
Maksik’s forceful novel illuminates the life of a Liberian woman who flees her troubled past to seek refuge on an Aegean island.
To immerse oneself in these poems is to enter a crowd of unusual characters: artistic geniuses, violent misfits, dramatic self-accusers (including the poet himself).
In these emotionally charged and gorgeously constructed poems, Shaughnessy imagines a world without a child’s pain.
In Gaige’s scenic novel, a man with a long-established false identity goes on the run with his 6-year-old daughter.
In this winning novel by the author of “Eat, Pray, Love,” a botanist’s hunger for explanations carries her through the better part of Darwin’s century, and to Tahiti.
Through scattered recollections, this novel sifts the significance of an ordinary life.
Members of a Texas clan grope their way from the ordeals of the frontier to celebrity culture’s absurdities in this masterly multigenerational saga.
This gripping Colombian novel, built on the country’s tragic history with the drug trade, meditates on love, fate and death.
This hard-edged, well-written novel involves a terrorist hostage-taking and a perilous deep-sea dive.
Amid dark humor both mournful and absurd, former classmates converge on the hilltop estate of a friend who has died in a freak accident.
Mathis’s deeply felt first novel works at the rough edges of history, within a brutal and poetic allegory of a black family beset by tribulations after the Great Migration to the North.
In Leavitt’s atmospheric novel of 1940 Lisbon, as two couples await passage to New York, the husbands embark on an affair.
This wrenching novel by the author of “The Joy Luck Club” follows mother and daughter courtesans over four decades.
Linking disparate characters and story threads, Miles’s novel explores varieties of waste and decay in a consumer world.

Título: We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves
sinopsis: This surreptitiously smart novel’s big reveal slyly recalls a tabloid headline: “Girl and Chimp Twinned at Birth in Psychological ­Experiment.”
A Zimbabwean moves to Detroit in Bulawayo’s striking first novel.
Maazel’s restlessly antic novel examines the concurrent urges for solitude and intimacy.
Messud’s ingenious, disquieting novel of outsize conflicts tells the story of a thwarted artist who finds herself bewitched by a boy and his parents.
This ambitious study, based on Abramsky’s travels around the country meeting the poor, both describes and prescribes.
A noted Harvard historian looks at the chaotic decades between Jamestown and King Philip’s War.
Indian-Americans populate every aspect of this meticulously reported true-life business thriller.
Bass reveals the sordid White House diplomacy that attended the birth of Bangladesh in 1971.
Ben Franklin’s sister bore 12 children and mostly led a life of hardship, but the two corresponded constantly.
In his memoir, Rosenblatt recalls being a boy learning to see, and to live, in the city he scrutinizes.
Historical parallels in Goodwin’s latest time machine implicitly ask us to look at our own age.
Johnson’s fascinating look at cancer reveals certain profound truths about life itself.
This excellent chronicle of World War I’s first months by a British military historian dispels some popular myths.
A disquieting but riveting examination of nuclear risk.
O’Brien reflects on a fraught and distinguished life, from the restraints of her Irish childhood to literary stardom.
A masterly Civil War-era history, full of foiled schemes, misfired plans and less-than-happy ­endings.
Chang portrays Cixi as a proto-feminist and reformer in this authoritative account.
Digressive essays, loosely about storytelling, reflect a difficult year in Solnit’s life.
The author of “The Looming Tower” takes a calm and neutral stance toward Scientology, but makes clear it’s like no other church on earth.
The final volume of Atkinson’s monumental war trilogy shows that the road to Berlin was far from smooth.
He was vain, gluttonous, promiscuous and none too bright, but “Bertie” emerges as an appealing character in Ridley’s superb book.
A searing memoir of a young woman’s brutal kidnapping in Somalia.
A commanding biography by a Harvard professor.
Butler’s study of the flaws in end-of-life care mixes personal narrative and tough reporting.
By contextualizing T. E. Lawrence, Anderson is able to address modern themes like oil, jihad and the Arab-Jewish conflict.
The lesson conveyed loud and clear by the Facebook executive is that women should step forward and not doubt their ability to combine work and family.
Cases of troubled young Internet prostitutes murdered on Long Island.
The poet muses knowingly and merrily on language, writing and speaking sentences that last lifetimes.
Guinn’s tour de force examines Manson’s rise and fall, the 1960s music industry and the decade’s bizarre ambience.
Fuller’s extensive intellectual accomplishments are set in contrast with her romantic disappointments.
A raw, beautiful elegy for Ward’s brother and four male friends, who died young in Mississippi between 2000 and 2004.
A remarkable look at the white women who sought a place in the Harlem Renaissance.
Mostly skirting her legal views, the Supreme Court justice’s memoir reveals much about her family, school and years at Princeton.
Shavit, a columnist for Haaretz, expresses both solidarity with and criticism of his countrymen in this important and powerful book.
The British wayfarer and travel writer is the subject of Cooper’s affectionate, informed biography.
Focusing on an unheralded but heroic Brooklyn classics professor, Fox turns the decipherment of Linear B into a detective story.
Refusing to make ’60s avatars of the unlikely couple behind a 1972 skyjacking, Koerner finds a deeper truth about the nature of extremism.

Título: The Smartest Kids in the World
sinopsis: A look at countries that are outeducating us — Finland, South Korea, Poland — through the eyes of American high school students abroad.
Finkel tracks soldiers struggling to navigate postwar life, especially the psychologically wounded.
This robust cultural history weaves together the stories of the artists, styles and ideas that developed in Chicago before and after World War II.
An entertaining and deeply troubling view of Washington.
The savage political dispute between Roosevelt and the isolationist movement, presented in spellbinding detail.
Digital-age transparency may threaten the spirit of democracy, Morozov warns.
Beam’s wrenching study is a triumph of narrative reporting and storytelling.
The Mideast expert makes the case for living with a nuclear Iran and trying to contain it.
With a nod to John Dos Passos, Packer offers a gripping narrative survey of today’s hard times; the 2013 National Book Award winner for nonfiction.
Why did the peace fail, a Canadian historian asks, and she offers superb portraits of the men who took Europe to war in the summer of 1914.
Mooallem explores the haphazard nature of our efforts to protect endangered ­species.
This lively history shows how the Good War turned out badly for many people and splendidly for others less deserving.
A Brooklyn-based narrator preoccupied with identity decides to help his best friend have a child in this frequently brilliant second novel.
With great sadness and much hard truth, Mengestu’s novel looks at a relationship of shared dependencies between a Midwestern social worker and a bereft African immigrant.
Wyld’s emotionally wrenching novel traces a solitary sheep farmer’s attempt to outrun her past on a remote British island.
Most of these stories offer variations on a particular sort of woman: in her 30s, urban, emotionally adrift.
One has the sense that Mantel is working with some complex private material in these suavely stylish, vastly entertaining contemporary fables.

Título: The Ballad of a Small Player
sinopsis: In Osborne’s feverish novel, the playing is done on the gambling tables of Macau by a tortured embezzler on the run.
The uncrowded format of Moore’s first collection in 16 years allows each story the chance it deserves for leisurely appreciation, and lets the reader savor just what makes her work unique.
Hustvedt’s multifaceted novel is a portrait of a creative titan whose career and reputation have seemingly been blighted by the art establishment’s ingrained sexism.
In this latest head-­spinning flight into other dimensions from the author of “Cloud Atlas,” all borders between pubby England and the machinations of the undead begin to blur.

Título: The Book of Strange New Things
sinopsis: Faber is a master of the weird; in his defiantly unclassifiable novel, a pastor from Earth is picked to satisfy an alien planet’s mysterious yen for religious instruction.
Latino immigrant characters face the challenges of assimilation.
Taking “Snow White” as a cultural touchstone, Oyeyemi’s novel offers up a cautionary tale on post-race ideology, racial limbos and the politics of passing.

Título: A Brief History of Seven Killings
sinopsis: Revolving around the assassination attempt on Bob Marley in 1976, this mesmerizingly powerful novel addresses politics, class, race and violence in ­Jamaica.
In Davis’s stories, the mundane and the fathomless appear together on the same street, and calamity is always close at hand.
Ullmann’s novel of a guilt-ridden Norwegian family is set in motion by a nanny’s murder.

Título: Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage
sinopsis: A novel of a man’s traumatic entrance into adulthood and the shadowy passages he must then ­negotiate.
In O’Neill’s disturbing, elegant novel, his first since “Netherland,” a lost and tormented New York lawyer recognizes more darkness within himself than in the iniquitous place he works, Dubai.
In this novel, a tragedy tears away at a mixed-race family in 1970s Ohio.
Deserted by their enigmatic father, three brothers struggle with life in Kehlmann’s sly tragicomedy.
The poet’s latest collection responds with high art and startling presence to the vantage offered by mortality.
In Henderson’s impressive novel, an overburdened social worker becomes involved with a near-feral boy and his survivalist father in 1980 Montana.

Título: A Girl is a Half-Formed Thing
sinopsis: An Irish writer’s odd, energetic first novel.
Lazar’s brilliant novel of spiritual discovery features Meyer Lansky, an American journalist and an Israeli poet’s murder.
Johnson’s cheerfully nihilistic novel about two scammers and rogue spies in Africa derives much of its situation from several of his early journalistic pieces.
Ulinich’s graphic novel traces the marital and romantic adventures of her immigrant heroine.

Título: Let Me Be Frank with You
sinopsis: In four linked stories, Ford’s aging Everyman surveys life after Hurricane Sandy batters New ­Jersey.
A young woman with a past of hardship and suffering makes a new start in Robinson’s fictional town of Gilead, Iowa.

Título: Lovers at the Chameleon Club, Paris 1932
sinopsis: Prose, a subtle psychologist, has created a genuinely evil character in Lou Villars, a cross-dressing French racecar driver and Nazi collaborator.
In the strong final installment of a trilogy, an exiled magician attempts a risky heist.
Estebanico, the first black explorer of America, narrates this fictional memoir.
Lockwood offers a collection at once angrier, and more fun, more attuned to our time and more bizarre, than most poetry can ever get.
The third installment of Knausgaard’s Proustian six-volume autobiographical novel.

Título: The Narrow Road to the Deep North
sinopsis: A frail humanity survives the unspeakable in this novel of the Burma-­Thailand Railway of World War II.
In Toibin’s luminous, elliptical novel, set in the late 1960s and early ’70s, an Irishwoman struggles toward independence after her husband’s unexpected death.
As a Ukrainian family adapts to life in Brooklyn, old-country memories linger.
Hard times, forbidden love, murder and justice are the themes of this nevertheless comic novel, set in London after World War I.
Stroke by patient stroke, the poems in this largehearted and essential selection from Walcott, now 84, are the work of a painterly hand.
In Johnston’s skillful and enthralling debut novel, a family is reunited after an abducted son comes home.
In Fishman’s bold, ambitious and wickedly smart first novel, a Soviet émigré writer in New York becomes disturbingly adept at forging applications for Holocaust reparations.
Allen’s masterly novel blends the personal story of the enslaved autistic piano prodigy Thomas Wiggins with the history of the Civil War and Reconstruction.
Minot’s novel approaches the atrocities wrought by a murderous African rebel army with candor yet without sensationalism.

Título: Those Who Leave and Those Who Stay
sinopsis: The third novel in Ferrante’s series, which tracks a long and complicated friendship.
Zink’s heady, rambunctious debut is an environmental novel, if a totally surprising and irreverent one.
Thomas’s gorgeous family epic follows three Irish-American generations.
This dark, rich little novel in stories shows Founds as a talented moralist of nearly Russian ferocity.

Título: 100 Essays I Don't Have Time to Write
sinopsis: The playwright on how to be creative when life and children intervene.
Tobar graphically recounts the quandaries faced by the victims of Chile’s 2010 mine disaster.
Solomon pays honest respect to Rockwell for his dedication through periods of self-doubt, depression and marital tumult.
A meditation on living better with age-related frailty, serious illness and approaching death.
What emerges here is the gaping chasm between what the best teachers do and how they are evaluated.
French delves into the actual lives of the Chinese who have uprooted themselves to live and work in Africa.
This account of office design and technology since the Civil War offers insights into the changing nature of work.
Percy’s first book follows an anguished Army veteran who searches for salvation in a Christian exorcism camp.
One of the few Obama administration members who come off well in this frank account — probably one of the best Washington memoirs ever — is Hillary Clinton.
A classicist tries to unravel the enigma of the Stoic philosopher who was the Roman emperor Nero’s adviser.
The Eichmann of this study is a much more motivated Nazi than in Arendt’s version.
A rich portrait of a fascinating Englishman in extraordinary times.
The Confederate president as “a product of his time and circumstances.”
